Posts.Content: Ho Mary...I note you are ER/PR+...therefore presumably taking tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor. These are a very likely cause of your continuing pain, rather than the chemo.You may be able to change from one to another, to get some relief. Sam
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen

Posts.Title: bone, muscle, and joint pain

Posts.Content: Hi! I was reading about this just recently. Apparently 15 minutes exposure to sunlight is enough to get your daily vitamin D.....and sunscreens can limit the amount of light your body can metabolise into vit D. So it would seem sensible to get your exposure at a time of day when the sun's rays are least harmful. BTW - I live in UK, so not much danger of over-exposure here......we don't often see the sun! I am also taking calcium+vitD supplement, so hopefully getting enough. Angel - my skin has also become very dry.....I have tried all kinds of creams and lotions. Any ideas? Sam
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen

Posts.Title: AlaskaAngel

Posts.Content: Oh yes.....taxotere does give you joint pain.....and muscle pain (actually that was worse for me)....and it also took a long time to go away after treatment.(sorry) But I wonder if you are getting either neupogen or neulasta for your WBC? They are notorious for giving pain, particularly in the lower back and the "long" bones.....actually a lot more severe than pain from taxotere.I experienced severe pain with my first lot of neupogen shots, but the subsequent ones were a lot less painful, more like aches and not really a problem. Hope your pains resolve soon! Sam
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen
Posts.Title: Taxotere Joint Pain

Posts.Content: Pam - Tamoxifen is for pre- AND post-menopausal women......Aromatase inhibitors (of which arimidex is but one) are for post-menopausal women only.It is that simple. You can take tamoxifen right now without anything else being "done" to you. You could get ovarian ablation or zoladex shots to shut down your ovaries if you wish to take arimidex. Most pre-menopausal women are on tamoxifen.(There are usually other circumstances where ovarian shut-down + an aromatase inhibitor is recommended). Sam
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Yes Leo - I think these would be great additions to an already excellent site. (Can I just ask you what a "blog" is?.....not too computer-literate, as you can see). When you talk of publishing, do you mean you would put up information which has recently been published in scientific and medical journals/ at conferences about various treatments etc? That would be a brilliant addition. Thank you for all your time and attention. You're doing a great job!! Sam

Posts.Title: website addition

Posts.Content: Hi Happyrock - Her2+ tumors tend to be more aggressive - but the good news is that there is a good treatment in the form of Herceptin - you should ask to enrol on a trial for this, as it is still only prescribed for advanced bc. BTW - was your Her2 status diagnosed with the IHC test ? I know that this can give false positives.If so, ask to be retested with the more accurate FISH test. It is all very confusing at first - you will feel better once your treatment protocol has been worked out. Sam
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen
Posts.Title: HER2NEU Positive

Posts.Content: I have just been switched to aromasin after 2 and a half years on tamoxifen (for early bc). My oncologist said that the trials have looked at this protocol, rather than tamoxifen followed by arimidex, which is what I was expecting to get. My question is - is there a disadvantage to aromasin, as I know it is the only one of the 3 aromatase inhibitors which is steroidal, and that the effects are supposedly "irreversible". (Which effects???) Also, could you tell me about potential side-effects..... Is there anyone else out there who has done a similar switch, or been taking aromasin from the start? I am feeling a bit nervous about taking this...... Thanks! Sam
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen
Posts.Title: aromasin (exemestane)- DrLeo ? and others.....

Posts.Content: Hi DrLeo - thanks for your reply above...... But do you know the answer to my original questions? What are the "irreversible" effects of aromasin? What does it signify that aromasin is the only "steroidal" aromatase inhibitor? (I have read that it should more accurately be called an aromatase inactivator) If you could answer these questions I would be very grateful. Thanks, Sam

Posts.Content: Happy and Healthy New Year to all on this site .....may we all be dancing with NED for a very long time Sam xx
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen
Posts.Title: Happy and HEALTHY New Year

Posts.Content: I have been taking tamoxifen since August 2002 with NO hot flashes!!! But have just been switched to aromasin as I have a large fibroid which will keep on growing on tamoxifen. Supplements? - Calcium + Vit D Selenium Magnesium Vitamin C .....and Fosamax as I have osteopenia of the spine. I eat no red meat, only free range chicken and fish.Been dairy-free for 3 years ( since diagnosis). Blessings to all, Sam x
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen
Posts.Title: What are you taking?

Posts.Content: Hi - from London, UK My "screen" name is Sam and I'm 53. I am the sole parent of a 21 year -old young man who has Asperger's Syndrome (autistic spectrum disorder). I was diagnosed at the end of October 2001 and had a mast and axilliary clearance at the end of November, so I have just passed the 3 year anniversary. My pathology was stage II,grade 3, 1.6cm IDC with surrounding DCIS, 3/11 nodes positive and ER/PR positive. I was in the TACT trial and had 4 x FEC and 4 x Taxotere followed by 25 rads.I finished treatment in August 2002, and am now taking tamoxifen. I only came to internet discussion boards just over a year ago - why didn't I think of doing it when I was first diagnosed? It has been a source of great support to find the bc.org board which led me here - so many wonderful people who really UNDERSTAND !! Thank you all and thankyou to Dr.Leo! Stay well, Sam xx
Posts.Signature: dx bc Oct 2001 tx - mast, chemo(FEC+taxotere), 25 rads.Now on tamoxifen
Posts.Title: How about a roll call?

Posts.Content: Hi Dr. Lu! I have posted on this subject before......but what I am looking for is an answer to a very specific question.....I'm hoping you will be able to help. Aromasin/exemestane works in a different way from the other aromatase inhibitors; it is both steroidal and its effects are irreversible.Indeed, it is described in some literature as an aromatase inactivator. My question is - what exactly does it signify that its effects are irreversible? Does this mean that when I stop taking it, the aromatase enzyme will still be inactivated? What implications might this have for my future well-being ? If you could explain this to me, I would be very grateful. Sam

Posts.Title: How about a roll call?

Posts.Content: A friend of mine did a free cholesterol test in Boots the chemist (in UK), about one year after finishing chemo; it was very elevated and the pharmacist told her it was probably a side-effect of the treatment, and a known problem after chemo. I am planning to get mine tested in the new year .....just another thing to look forward to...... Sam

Posts.Title: How about a roll call?

Posts.Content: This was all over the news yesterday here in the UK - I think they always over-emphasise the potential benefit, but nevertheless it is there. I just have to try and convince my oncologist to switch me over from tamoxifen to arimidex - I have been trying (unsuccessfully) for over 2 years. She keeps saying "not enough long-term reporting", but now surely this will be enough? No doubt our socialised, and therefore free, Health Service will put a block on switching women from a drug that costs £25 per annum to one that costs £1000 ; but I intend to persuade her if I can . Sam
